DataElement.preferredName: Chronic Graft Versus Host Disease Diagnostic Criteria Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Term to describe clinical manifestation(s) used to diagnose chronic Graft versus Host Disease (cGVHD).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Chronic Graft Versus Host Disease Diagnostic Criterion
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The assessment of the transplant recipient for signs and symptoms of chronic Graft versus Host Disease (GVHD)._An incompatibility reaction (which may be fatal) in a subject (host) of low immunological competence (deficient lymphoid tissue) who has been the recipient of immunologically competent lymphoid tissue from a donor who lacks at least one antigen possessed by the recipient host; the reaction, or disease, is the result of action of the transplanted cells against those host tissues that possess the antigen not possessed by the donor. Seen most commonly following bone marrow transplantation, acute disease is seen after 5-40 days and chronic disease weeks to months after transplantation, affecting, principally, the gastrointestinal tract, liver, and skin._A disease or condition that persists or progresses over a long period of time._Characteristic or indicative of (e.g., a disease)._Criteria; a basis for comparison; a reference point against which other things can be evaluated.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A disease or condition that persists or progresses over a long period of time.:An incompatibility reaction (which may be fatal) in a subject (host) of low immunological competence (deficient lymphoid tissue) who has been the recipient of immunologically competent lymphoid tissue from a donor who lacks at least one antigen possessed by the recipient host; the reaction, or disease, is the result of action of the transplanted cells against those host tissues that possess the antigen not possessed by the donor. Seen most commonly following bone marrow transplantation, acute disease is seen after 5-40 days and chronic disease weeks to months after transplantation, affecting, principally, the gastrointestinal tract, liver, and skin.

Concepts.definition: Usually used to describe a condition that is persistent and long standing.

A reaction, which may be fatal, in an immunocompromised subject (host) who has received an antigenically incompatible tissue transplant (graft) from an immunocompetent donor. The reaction is secondary to the activation of the transplanted cells against those host tissues that express an antigen not expressed by the donor, and is seen most commonly following bone marrow transplantation; acute disease is seen after 5-40 days, and chronic disease occurs weeks to months after transplantation.

Property.preferredDefinition: Characteristic or indicative of (e.g., a disease).:Criteria; a basis for comparison; a reference point against which other things can be evaluated.

Concepts.definition: Characteristic or indicative of a condition.
That which constitutes a standard from which a judgment can be established, a reference point against which other things can be evaluated, or a basis for comparison.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Text terms describing symptoms of chronic Graft vs. Host Disease (GVHD) that involve the skin._That which constitutes a standard from which a judgment can be established, a reference point against which other things can be evaluated, or a basis for comparison.

PermissibleValues.value: Restriction of mouth opening from sclerosis

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathological hardening or thickening of tissue, especially that of the interstitial substance.: The cavity lying at the upper end of the alimentary canal, bounded on the outside by the lips and inside by the oropharynx and containing in humans the tongue, gums, and teeth.: Anything that limits; a limitation.

Concepts.definition: A pathological hardening or thickening of tissue, especially that of the interstitial substance.
The cavity located at the upper end of the alimentary canal, behind the teeth and gums that is bounded on the outside by the lips, above by the hard and soft palates and below by the tongue.
Anything that limits; a limitation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Hypertrophy of the outermost layer of the epidermis. It maybe caused by physical or chemical irritants, irradiation, infection, or neoplastic processes.: A biofilm that contains numerous microorganisms that adheres to the teeth.

Concepts.definition: Hypertrophy of the outermost layer of the epidermis. It may be caused by physical or chemical irritants, irradiation, infection, or neoplastic processes.
A biofilm that contains numerous microorganisms that adheres to the teeth.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having the characteristics of a chronic, recurrent, pruritic inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology that affects the skin and mucus membranes. It presents with rashes and papules that tend to resolve spontaneously. It may be associated with hepatitis C. Certain drugs that contain arsenic or bismuth are associated with reactions mimicking lichen planus.: A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

Concepts.definition: Having the characteristics of a chronic, recurrent, pruritic inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology that affects the skin and mucus membranes. It presents with rashes and papules that tend to resolve spontaneously. It may be associated with hepatitis C. Certain drugs that contain arsenic or bismuth are associated with reactions mimicking lichen planus.
A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic inflammatory process affecting the skin. It is characterized by the presence of white, indurated plaques, epidermal atrophy, and fibrosis of the upper dermis. It usually appears in the vulva and penis.: A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

Concepts.definition: A chronic inflammatory process affecting the skin. It is characterized by the presence of white, indurated plaques, epidermal atrophy, and fibrosis of the upper dermis. It usually appears in the vulva and penis.
A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Skin Morphea-Type (Sclerosing) Basal Cell Carcinoma Feature

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Skin Morphea-Type (Sclerosing) Basal Cell Carcinoma Feature
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No Value Exists: A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

Concepts.definition: A histologic variant of basal cell carcinoma of the skin characterized by the presence of strands and nests of malignant cells that are embedded in a dense fibrotic stroma.
A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An inflammatory, pruritic disease of the skin and mucous membranes, which can be either generalized or localized. It is characterized by distinctive purplish, flat-topped papules having a predilection for the trunk and flexor surfaces. The lesions may be discrete or coalesce to form plaques. Histologically, there is a "saw-tooth" pattern of epidermal hyperplasia and vacuolar alteration of the basal layer of the epidermis along with an intense upper dermal inflammatory infiltrate composed predominantly of T-cells. Etiology is unknown.: A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

Concepts.definition: A chronic, recurrent, pruritic inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology that affects the skin and mucus membranes. It presents with rashes and papules that tend to resolve spontaneously. It may be associated with hepatitis C. Certain drugs that contain arsenic or bismuth are associated with reactions mimicking lichen planus.
A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A localized skin condition commonly associated with sun exposure that is characterized by variegated discoloration, telangiectasia and atrophy.

Concepts.definition: A localized skin condition commonly associated with sun exposure that is characterized by variegated discoloration, telangiectasia and atrophy.

PermissibleValues.value: Joint stiffness or contractures secondary to sclerosis

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A sensation of discomfort and tightness while moving a joint. Typically there is decreased joint range of motion. Causes include arthritis, joint overuse, joint injury, and the aging process.: Derived as a result of a primary condition; not direct or immediate; of second rank or importance or value.: A pathological hardening or thickening of tissue, especially that of the interstitial substance.

Concepts.definition: A sensation of discomfort and tightness while moving a joint. Typically there is decreased joint range of motion. Causes include arthritis, joint overuse, joint injury, and the aging process.
Derived as a result of a primary condition; not direct or immediate; of second rank or importance or value.
A pathological hardening or thickening of tissue, especially that of the interstitial substance.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Relating to the vagina or to any sheath.: The formation of new tissue in the process of wound healing.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: Narrowing or stricture of a duct or canal.

Concepts.definition: Of or relating to the vagina.
A permanent mark left on the skin in the process of wound healing.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
Narrowing or stricture of a vessel, duct or canal.
Inflammation process in fascia.

PermissibleValues.value: Bronchiolitis obliterans diagnosed with lung biopsy

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Inflammation of the bronchioles with obstruction by fibrous granulation tissue or bronchial exudate. It may follow inhalation of irritating gases or foreign bodies and it complicates pneumonia.: Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.: Removal of tissue from the lung, for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: Inflammation of the bronchioles with obstruction by fibrous granulation tissue or bronchial exudate. It may follow inhalation of irritating gases or foreign bodies and it complicates pneumonia.
Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.
Removal of tissue from the lung, for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Inflammation of the bronchioles with obstruction by fibrous granulation tissue or bronchial exudate. It may follow inhalation of irritating gases or foreign bodies and it complicates pneumonia.

PermissibleValues.value: Strictures or stenosis in upper to mid-third of esophagus
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Strictures or Stenosis Upper Third to Middle Third of the Esophagus

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Strictures or Stenosis Upper Third to Middle Third of the Esophagus
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Narrowing or stricture of a vessel, duct or canal.: The upper one third of esophagus in which the muscle layer is composed of muscle cells of the striated type.: The middle one third of the esophagus in which the muscle layer is composed of muscle cells of the striated and smooth types.: The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.

Concepts.definition: Narrowing or stricture of a vessel, duct or canal.
The upper one third of esophagus in which the muscle layer is composed of muscle cells of the striated type.
The middle one third of the esophagus in which the muscle layer is composed of muscle cells of the striated and smooth types.
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A thin membrane that is present in the esophageal lumen. It is composed of mucosa and submucosa and it may be associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Concepts.definition: A thin membrane that is present in the esophageal lumen. It is composed of mucosa and submucosa and it may be associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

PermissibleValues.value: Phimosis or urethral/meatus scarring or stenosis
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Phimosis or urethral/meatus scarring or stenosis

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Phimosis or urethral/meatus scarring or stenosis
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A condition in which there is constriction in the tip of the foreskin resulting in inability to fully retract the foreskin over the glans penis.  Causes include balanoposthitis, balanitis xerotica obliterans, and untreated diabetes.: The tube carrying urine from the bladder to outside of the body.: Narrowing or stricture of a vessel, duct or canal.: The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.

Concepts.definition: A condition in which there is constriction in the tip of the foreskin resulting in inability to fully retract the foreskin over the glans penis.  Causes include balanoposthitis, balanitis xerotica obliterans, and untreated diabetes.
The tube carrying urine from the bladder to outside of the body.
Narrowing or stricture of a vessel, duct or canal.
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.
